text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full-page pictorial composition with central roundel, two triangular medallions above and below, and four square corner panels; small script captions in narrow strips at top and bottom; no continuous text block.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for halos and decorative backgrounds; alternating bands of red and blue define geometric borders; white highlights accentuate folds and foliage; pigments are layered to model drapery and architectural frames; overall palette remains vivid with minimal darkening.

features: Central circular roundel with enthroned saint
Four square corner panels with distinct figures

decorative_elements: Interlaced vine scrolls with foliate motifs
Gothic micro-architecture frames with arches and pinnacles
Diapered gold backgrounds punched with patterns
Floral ornament in red, blue, green and white
Greek-key band borders in contrasting colors

drawing_technique.line_style: Bold dark-brown outlines with finer internal hatch lines in drapery and foliage
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal hatching; volume indicated by layered color washes and white highlights
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping arches; no attempt at vanishing-point perspective

Interlaced vine-scroll motif in every frame

content_theme.scene_description: The central roundel depicts a haloed male saint seated on a stylized bench composed of arcaded supports against a red, gold-punched background. He wears an azurite-blue cloak over an ochre robe, his right hand raised in a gesture of blessing and his left hand holding a long, unfurled scroll inscribed with Latin text. His feet rest lightly on the bench seat, one leg crossed, the other dangling. The bench’s miniature arches mirror the larger architectural frames throughout. Halos and gilded backgrounds define sanctity. Above and below, triangular medallions contain an angel bearing a scroll and a laborer with a sickle among sprouting stalks, symbolizing heavenly message and seasonal work. At four corners, square panels show three ecclesiastics, the Madonna and Child, a bishop with crozier, and a seated scholar, each under matching arches and against vine-scroll fills. The rigid geometric grid unifies them, with key-pattern bands in red, blue, green, and white separating registers. Figures engage visually through shared color motifs, directional gazes, and repeated decorative details that tie the allegorical program of divine counsel, intercession, earthly labors, and learned authority into a coherent whole.

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum with uniformly smooth, cream-toned surface and faint hair-follicle pattern visible under magnification
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments remain vivid with minimal oxidation; slight flaking of red in border areas; narrow contemporary repair at lower margin; overall stable
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso beneath gold leaf for low relief
Underdrawing visible in brown pigment under ultraviolet
Plummet ruling for precise geometric grid
Fine brush strokes in layered pigment application

secondary_functions: Memory aid for the liturgical year

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This full-page illumination exemplifies a late 13th-century workshop’s mastery of geometric and allegorical program. The symmetrical grid unites divine, ecclesiastical, and earthly realms into a coherent meditational schema: the central saint as intercessor, angelic annunciation above, seasonal labor below, and supporting ecclesiastical and learned figures in the corners. The lavish use of burnished gold leaf, azurite blue, and minium red—applied in layered washes with white highlights and intricate punchwork—speaks to a high-end commission, likely for a noble patron’s book of hours or devotional miscellany. Technical evidence of raised gesso and precise plummet ruling aligns with Parisian illuminators’ practices under the influence of the Master of the Westminster Psalter. Iconographically, the interplay of scrolls, halos, and micro-architectural frames reflects a theological program linking heavenly authority to temporal duties. Compared with contemporary manuscripts such as the Hours of Jeanne d’Évreux, this page shows a more rigid geometric framework but shares the vocabulary of vine-scroll ornament and lavish gilding. The inclusion of a seasonal laborer recalls calendar folios yet here serves allegory rather than chronological function, demonstrating an innovative fusion of calendrical imagery and theological reflection characteristic of transitional Gothic art in northern France.
